planning.txt File Reference


Functions

The main focus of the P3
solution is so it has to be
lean and mean We have to avoid
anything that adds overhead
Since there won t be any
client applications that
connect to the primary and
secondary P3 file and web
server software is not needed
The P3 systems will act like
routers and sit in the path of
traffic between data centers
In fact they will have some
low level routing
functionality Almost all of
this will have to be original
but it should not be extremely
complicated The Mocana code we
will use is the IPSec handler
and the encryption engine We
will modify the IPSec code
slightly The big question is
key which is a database
application We cannot afford
the overhead of a standalone
database management we need to
find a simple DB that can
become part of the application
The Berkeley DB is this type
of but there might be
licensing issues I believe
there are other but I do not
have experience with them I am
hoping that a developer with
experience in this type of
application can be brought on
and will give us the pros and
cons of a few solutions
Failover and load balancing
are built into the operating
system The thing is that load
balancing expects many
relatively short lived
connections The P3 solution is
a single long lived so that
would have to be modified to
handle the difference Since
these are to be the code doesn
t have to be general which
makes it somewhat simpler The
only considerations that have
to be made will be for
potential upgrades to the
appliance hardware The S2
solution is a somewhat
different beast Performance
will be of some because the
file system will wait for a
key and then for encryption
decryption before it can
forward a file to its next
destination since it all takes
place in a single data center
over a high speed we will have
more control over performance
factors It should be possible
to leverage key management
from the P3 with some
differences in the table
definitions And we will use
the Mocana encryption without
any changes to their code for
the encryption engine Also the
standard built in failover
functionality should work for
this solution The biggest
challenge here is the agents
This requires a strong
knowledge of the specific file
systems to be supported
Finding the right people for
this will be critical for
delivering a product in a
reasonable amount of time With
all of that before we begin I
would like to have a source
code management system in
place If Velocite Systems does
not already have I recommend
subversion The question is
where it will reside If there
is administrator access to the
Velocite Systems web that
would be the perfect and the
amount of traffic added would
be minimal Otherwise a
suitable host needs to be
designated we need to plan for
testing This could be done on
a moderately powered server
virtual running or a few
smaller servers The key is
that they need to be set up
with procedures and automated
scripts established so that
whoever needs to run a test
can do so efficiently I am
assuming that there are plenty
of people at Velocite Systems
who could handle but we need
to plan for how much of their
time it will require And last
but not documentation This
always requires input from the
and if it is left to the last
is usually a larger task than
you would expect It would be
best to have someone in charge
of creating the format and
then establishing a procedure
for developers to feed
information to this person as
functions are completed As far
as building the development
Bob wants to focus on the P3
solution first The S2 solution
could be ramped up while the
P3 solution is still being but
I am not planning on that
happening At this I know what
needs to be but I haven t
tried to break it out to
determine how long it will
take Basically I see at least
developers for the P3 and
maybe including an admin
interface Platform because my
back is killing me if it is
absolutely necessary to meet
face to face on give me a
couple of hours notice and I
will take an extra Advil and
come to Glen Burnie But if you
have specific issues you would
like to I would prefer to give
you my recommendations in an
Email Jim Sansing Ritasa LLC
Bill Bree Thanks for your
phone call I m sorry I missed
you Am also sorry to hear of
your back problems Cook can
tell you of the many back
problems have had The subject
of discussion I d like to have
is centered around selecting
base platforms for each of the
functional areas of the system
and the rationale for the
selection For Mocana says on
their website that they have
an open source Non GPL File
Server do we want to consider
that or do we want to specify
a different licensed product
to support needed 		functions (failover?) that might not be present in the Mocana system? > > I think that the results of the discussion will be that we need to do > some considerable mining work to uncover the current state

Failover and load balancing
are built into the operating
system The thing is that load
balancing expects many
relatively short lived
connections The P3 solution is
a single long lived so that
would have to be modified to
handle the difference Since
these are to be the code doesn
t have to be general which
makes it somewhat simpler The
only considerations that have
to be made will be for
potential upgrades to the
appliance hardware The S2
solution is a somewhat
different beast Performance
will be of some because the
file system will wait for a
key and then for encryption
decryption before it can
forward a file to its next
destination since it all takes
place in a single data center
over a high speed we will have
more control over performance
factors It should be possible
to leverage key management
from the P3 with some
differences in the table
definitions And we will use
the Mocana encryption without
any changes to their code for
the encryption engine Also the
standard built in failover
functionality should work for
this solution The biggest
challenge here is the agents
This requires a strong
knowledge of the specific file
systems to be supported
Finding the right people for
this will be critical for
delivering a product in a
reasonable amount of time With
all of that before we begin I
would like to have a source
code management system in
place If Velocite Systems does
not already have I recommend
subversion The question is
where it will reside If there
is administrator access to the
Velocite Systems web that
would be the perfect and the
amount of traffic added would
be minimal Otherwise a
suitable host needs to be
designated 		Next
The main focus of the P3
solution is so it has to be
lean and mean We have to avoid
anything that adds overhead
Since there won t be any
client applications that
connect to the primary and
secondary P3 file and web
server software is not needed
The P3 systems will act like
routers and sit in the path of
traffic between data centers
In fact they will have some
low level routing
functionality Almost all of
this will have to be original
but it should not be extremely
complicated The Mocana code we
will use is the IPSec handler
and the encryption engine We
will modify the IPSec code
slightly The big question is
key which is a database
application We cannot afford
the overhead of a standalone
database management we need to
find a simple DB that can
become part of the application
The Berkeley DB is this type
of but there might be
licensing issues I believe
there are other but I do not
have experience with them I am
hoping that a developer with
experience in this type of
application can be brought on
and will give us the pros and
cons of a few solutions
Failover and load balancing
are built into the operating
system The thing is that load
balancing expects many
relatively short lived
connections The P3 solution is
a single long lived so that
would have to be modified to
handle the difference Since
these are to be the code doesn
t have to be general which
makes it somewhat simpler The
only considerations that have
to be made will be for
potential upgrades to the
appliance hardware The S2
solution is a somewhat
different beast Performance
will be of some because the
file system will wait for a
key and then for encryption
decryption before it can
forward a file to its next

more control over performance
factors It should be possible
to leverage key management
from the P3 with some
differences in the table
definitions And we will use
the Mocana encryption without
any changes to their code for
the encryption engine Also the
standard built in failover
functionality should work for
this solution The biggest
challenge here is the agents

knowledge of the specific file
systems to be supported

The main focus of the P3
solution is so it has to be
lean and mean We have to avoid
anything that adds overhead
Since there won t be any
client applications that
connect to the primary and
secondary P3 file and web
server software is not needed
The P3 systems will act like
routers and sit in the path of
traffic between data centers
In fact they will have some
low level routing
functionality Almost all of
this will have to be original
but it should not be extremely
complicated The Mocana code we
will use is the IPSec handler
and the encryption engine We
will modify the IPSec code
slightly The big question is
key which is a database
application We cannot afford
the overhead of a standalone
database management we need to
find a simple DB that can
become part of the application
The Berkeley DB is this type
of but there might be
licensing issues I believe
there are other but I do not
have experience with them I am
hoping that a developer with
experience in this type of
application can be brought on
and will give us the pros and
cons of a few solutions

that they need to be set up
with procedures and automated
scripts established so that
whoever needs to run a test
can do so efficiently I am

of people at Velocite Systems

designated we need to plan for
testing This could be done on
a moderately powered server
virtual running or a few
smaller servers The key is
that they need to be set up
with procedures and automated
scripts established so that
whoever needs to run a test
can do so efficiently I am
assuming that there are plenty
of people at Velocite Systems
who could handle but we need
to plan for how much of their
time it will require And last
but not documentation This
always requires input from the
and if it is left to the last
is usually a larger task than
you would expect It would be
best to have someone in charge
of creating the format and
then establishing a procedure
for developers to feed
information to this person as
functions are completed As far
as building the development
Bob wants to focus on the P3
solution first The S2 solution
could be ramped up while the
P3 solution is still being but
I am not planning on that
happening At this I know what
needs to be 		done
The main focus of the P3
solution is so it has to be
lean and mean We have to avoid
anything that adds overhead
Since there won t be any
client applications that
connect to the primary and
secondary P3 file and web
server software is not needed
The P3 systems will act like
routers and sit in the path of
traffic between data centers
In fact they will have some
low level routing
functionality Almost all of
this will have to be original
but it should not be extremely
complicated The Mocana code we
will use is the IPSec handler
and the encryption engine We
will modify the IPSec code
slightly The big question is
key which is a database
application We cannot afford
the overhead of a standalone
database management we need to
find a simple DB that can
become part of the application
The Berkeley DB is this type
of but there might be
licensing issues I believe
there are other but I do not
have experience with them I am
hoping that a developer with
experience in this type of
application can be brought on
and will give us the pros and
cons of a few solutions
Failover and load balancing
are built into the operating
system The thing is that load
balancing expects many
relatively short lived
connections The P3 solution is
a single long lived so that
would have to be modified to
handle the difference Since
these are to be the code doesn
t have to be general which
makes it somewhat simpler The
only considerations that have
to be made will be for
potential upgrades to the
appliance hardware The S2
solution is a somewhat
different beast Performance
will be of some because the
file system will wait for a
key and then for encryption
decryption before it can
forward a file to its next
destination since it all takes
place in a single data center
over a high speed we will have
more control over performance
factors It should be possible
to leverage key management
from the P3 with some
differences in the table
definitions And we will use
the Mocana encryption without
any changes to their code for
the encryption engine Also the
standard built in failover
functionality should work for
this solution The biggest
challenge here is the agents
This requires a strong
knowledge of the specific file
systems to be supported
Finding the right people for
this will be critical for
delivering a product in a
reasonable amount of time With
all of that before we begin I
would like to have a source
code management system in
place If Velocite Systems does
not already have I recommend
subversion The question is
where it will reside If there
is administrator access to the
Velocite Systems web that
would be the perfect and the
amount of traffic added would
be minimal Otherwise a
suitable host needs to be
designated we need to plan for
testing This could be done on
a moderately powered server
virtual running or a few
smaller servers The key is
that they need to be set up
with procedures and automated
scripts established so that
whoever needs to run a test
can do so efficiently I am
assuming that there are plenty
of people at Velocite Systems
who could handle but we need
to plan for how much of their
time it will require And last
but not documentation This
always requires input from the
and if it is left to the last
is usually a larger task than
you would expect It would be
best to have someone in charge
of creating the format and
then establishing a procedure
for developers to feed
information to this person as
functions are completed As far
as building the development

solution is so it has to be

anything that adds overhead
Since there won t be any
client applications that

server software is not needed

low level routing
functionality Almost all of

slightly The big question is
key which is a database
application We cannot afford
the overhead of a standalone
database management we need to
find a simple DB that can
become part of the application

licensing issues I believe
there are other but I do not
have experience with them I am

experience in this type of
application can be brought on
and will give us the pros and
cons of a few solutions

connections The P3 solution is
a single long lived so that
would have to be modified to
handle the difference Since
these are to be the code doesn
t have to be general which
makes it somewhat simpler The
only considerations that have
to be made will be for
potential upgrades to the
appliance hardware The S2
solution is a somewhat
different beast Performance
will be of some because the
file system will wait for a
key and then for encryption
decryption before it can
forward a file to its next
destination since it all takes
place in a single data center
over a high speed we will have
more control over performance
factors It should be possible
to leverage key management
from the P3 with some
differences in the table
definitions And we will use
the Mocana encryption without
any changes to their code for
the encryption engine Also the
standard built in failover
functionality should work for
this solution The biggest
challenge here is the agents
This requires a strong
knowledge of the specific file
systems to be supported
Finding the right people for
this will be critical for
delivering a product in a
reasonable amount of time With
all of that before we begin I
would like to have a source
code management system in
place If Velocite Systems does
not already have I recommend
subversion The question is
where it will reside If there
is administrator access to the
Velocite Systems web that
would be the perfect and the
amount of traffic added would
be minimal Otherwise a
suitable host needs to be
designated we need to plan for
testing This could be done on
a moderately powered server
virtual running or a few
smaller servers The key is
that they need to be set up
with procedures and automated
scripts established so that
whoever needs to run a test
can do so efficiently I am
assuming that there are plenty
of people at Velocite Systems
who could handle but we need
to plan for how much of their
time it will require And last
but not documentation This
always requires input from the
and if it is left to the last
is usually a larger task than
you would expect It would be
best to have someone in charge
of creating the format and
then establishing a procedure
for developers to feed
information to this person as
functions are completed As far
as building the development
Bob wants to focus on the P3
solution first The S2 solution
could be ramped up while the
P3 solution is still being but
I am not planning on that
happening At this I know what
needs to be but I haven t
tried to break it out to
determine how long it will

The main focus of the P3
solution is so it has to be
lean and mean We have to avoid
anything that adds overhead
Since there won t be any
client applications that
connect to the primary and
secondary P3 file and web
server software is not needed
The P3 systems will act like
routers and sit in the path of
traffic between data centers
In fact they will have some
low level routing
functionality Almost all of
this will have to be original
but it should not be extremely
complicated The Mocana code we
will use is the IPSec handler
and the encryption engine We
will modify the IPSec code
slightly The big question is
key which is a database
application We cannot afford
the overhead of a standalone
database management we need to
find a simple DB that can
become part of the application
The Berkeley DB is this type
of but there might be
licensing issues I believe
there are other but I do not
have experience with them I am
hoping that a developer with
experience in this type of
application can be brought on
and will give us the pros and
cons of a few solutions
Failover and load balancing
are built into the operating
system The thing is that load
balancing expects many
relatively short lived
connections The P3 solution is
a single long lived so that
would have to be modified to
handle the difference Since
these are to be the code doesn
t have to be general which
makes it somewhat simpler The
only considerations that have
to be made will be for
potential upgrades to the
appliance hardware The S2
solution is a somewhat
different beast Performance
will be of some because the
file system will wait for a
key and then for encryption
decryption before it can
forward a file to its next
destination since it all takes
place in a single data center
over a high speed we will have
more control over performance
factors It should be possible
to leverage key management
from the P3 with some
differences in the table
definitions And we will use
the Mocana encryption without
any changes to their code for
the encryption engine Also the
standard built in failover
functionality should work for
this solution The biggest

Function Documentation

The main focus of the P3 solution is so it has to be lean and mean We have to avoid anything that adds overhead Since there won t be any client applications that connect to the primary and secondary P3 file and web server software is not needed The P3 systems will act like routers and sit in the path of traffic between data centers In fact they will have some low level routing functionality Almost all of this will have to be original but it should not be extremely complicated The Mocana code we will use is the IPSec handler and the encryption engine We will modify the IPSec code slightly The big question is key which is a database application We cannot afford the overhead of a standalone database management we need to find a simple DB that can become part of the application The Berkeley DB is this type of but there might be licensing issues I believe there are other but I do not have experience with them I am hoping that a developer with experience in this type of application can be brought on and will give us the pros and cons of a few solutions Failover and load balancing are built into the operating system The thing is that load balancing expects many relatively short lived connections The P3 solution is a single long lived so that would have to be modified to handle the difference Since these are to be the code doesn t have to be general which makes it somewhat simpler The only considerations that have to be made will be for potential upgrades to the appliance hardware The S2 solution is a somewhat different beast Performance will be of some because the file system will wait for a key and then for encryption decryption before it can forward a file to its next destination since it all takes place in a single data center over a high speed we will have more control over performance factors It should be possible to leverage key management from the P3 with some differences in the table definitions And we will use the Mocana encryption without any changes to their code for the encryption engine Also the standard built in failover functionality should work for this solution The biggest challenge here is the agents This requires a strong knowledge of the specific file systems to be supported Finding the right people for this will be critical for delivering a product in a reasonable amount of time With all of that before we begin I would like to have a source code management system in place If Velocite Systems does not already have I recommend subversion The question is where it will reside If there is administrator access to the Velocite Systems web that would be the perfect and the amount of traffic added would be minimal Otherwise a suitable host needs to be designated we need to plan for testing This could be done on a moderately powered server virtual running or a few smaller servers The key is that they need to be set up with procedures and automated scripts established so that whoever needs to run a test can do so efficiently I am assuming that there are plenty of people at Velocite Systems who could handle but we need to plan for how much of their time it will require And last but not documentation This always requires input from the and if it is left to the last is usually a larger task than you would expect It would be best to have someone in charge of creating the format and then establishing a procedure for developers to feed information to this person as functions are completed As far as building the development Bob wants to focus on the P3 solution first The S2 solution could be ramped up while the P3 solution is still being but I am not planning on that happening At this I know what needs to be but I haven t tried to break it out to determine how long it will take Basically I see at least developers for the P3 and maybe including an admin interface Platform because my back is killing me if it is absolutely necessary to meet face to face on give me a couple of hours notice and I will take an extra Advil and come to Glen Burnie But if you have specific issues you would like to I would prefer to give you my recommendations in an Email Jim Sansing Ritasa LLC Bill Bree Thanks for your phone call I m sorry I missed you Am also sorry to hear of your back problems Cook can tell you of the many back problems have had The subject of discussion I d like to have is centered around selecting base platforms for each of the functional areas of the system and the rationale for the selection For Mocana says on their website that they have an open source Non GPL File Server do we want to consider that or do we want to specify a different licensed product to support needed functions ( failover?   )  [virtual]

Variable Documentation

The main focus of the P3 solution is performance

The main focus of the P3 solution is so it has to be lean and mean We have to avoid anything that adds overhead Since there won t be any client applications that connect to the primary and secondary P3 systems

The main focus of the P3 solution is so it has to be lean and mean We have to avoid anything that adds overhead Since there won t be any client applications that connect to the primary and secondary P3 file and web server software is not needed The P3 systems will act like routers and sit in the path of traffic between data centers In fact they will have some low level routing functionality Almost all of this will have to be original code

The main focus of the P3 solution is so it has to be lean and mean We have to avoid anything that adds overhead Since there won t be any client applications that connect to the primary and secondary P3 file and web server software is not needed The P3 systems will act like routers and sit in the path of traffic between data centers In fact they will have some low level routing functionality Almost all of this will have to be original but it should not be extremely complicated The Mocana code we will use is the IPSec handler and the encryption engine We will modify the IPSec code slightly The big question is key which is a database application We cannot afford the overhead of a standalone database management we need to find a simple DB that can become part of the application The Berkeley DB is this type of but there might be licensing issues I believe there are other but I do not have experience with them I am hoping that a developer with experience in this type of application can be brought on and will give us the pros and cons of a few solutions Failover and load balancing are built into the operating system The thing is that load balancing expects many relatively short lived connections The P3 solution is a single long lived so that would have to be modified to handle the difference Since these are to be the code doesn t have to be general which makes it somewhat simpler The only considerations that have to be made will be for potential upgrades to the appliance hardware The S2 solution is a somewhat different beast Performance will be of some because the file system will wait for a key and then for encryption decryption before it can forward a file to its next destination since it all takes place in a single data center over a high speed we will have more control over performance factors It should be possible to leverage key management from the P3 with some differences in the table definitions And we will use the Mocana encryption without any changes to their code for the encryption engine Also the standard built in failover functionality should work for this solution The biggest challenge here is the agents This requires a strong knowledge of the specific file systems to be supported Finding the right people for this will be critical for delivering a product in a reasonable amount of time With all of that before we begin I would like to have a source code management system in place If Velocite Systems does not already have I recommend subversion The question is where it will reside If there is administrator access to the Velocite Systems web that would be the perfect and the amount of traffic added would be minimal Otherwise a suitable host needs to be designated we need to plan for testing This could be done on a moderately powered server virtual running or a few smaller servers The key is that they need to be set up with procedures and automated scripts established so that whoever needs to run a test can do so efficiently I am assuming that there are plenty of people at Velocite Systems who could handle but we need to plan for how much of their time it will require And last but not documentation This always requires input from the and if it is left to the last is usually a larger task than you would expect It would be best to have someone in charge of creating the format and then establishing a procedure for developers to feed information to this person as functions are completed As far as building the development Bob wants to focus on the P3 solution first The S2 solution could be ramped up while the P3 solution is still being but I am not planning on that happening At this I know what needs to be but I haven t tried to break it out to determine how long it will take Basically I see at least developers for the P3 solution

The main focus of the P3 solution is so it has to be lean and mean We have to avoid anything that adds overhead Since there won t be any client applications that connect to the primary and secondary P3 file and web server software is not needed The P3 systems will act like routers and sit in the path of traffic between data centers In fact they will have some low level routing functionality Almost all of this will have to be original but it should not be extremely complicated The Mocana code we will use is the IPSec handler and the encryption engine We will modify the IPSec code slightly The big question is key which is a database application We cannot afford the overhead of a standalone database management we need to find a simple DB that can become part of the application The Berkeley DB is this type of but there might be licensing issues I believe there are other choices

encryption without any changes to their code for the encryption engine Also the standard built in failover functionality should work for this solution The biggest challenge here is the agents This requires a strong knowledge of the specific file systems to be supported Finding the right people for this will be critical for delivering a product in a reasonable amount of time With all of that before we begin I would like to have a source code management system in place If Velocite Systems does not already have I recommend subversion The question is where it will reside If there is administrator access to the Velocite Systems web that would be the perfect and the amount of traffic added would be minimal Otherwise a suitable host needs to be designated we need to plan for testing This could be done on a moderately powered server virtual running or a few smaller servers The key is that they need to be set up with procedures and automated scripts established so that whoever needs to run a test can do so efficiently I am assuming that there are plenty of people at Velocite Systems who could handle this

The main focus of the P3 solution is so it has to be lean and mean We have to avoid anything that adds overhead Since there won t be any client applications that connect to the primary and secondary P3 file and web server software is not needed The P3 systems will act like routers and sit in the path of traffic between data centers In fact they will have some low level routing functionality Almost all of this will have to be original but it should not be extremely complicated The Mocana code we will use is the IPSec handler and the encryption engine We will modify the IPSec code slightly The big question is key which is a database application We cannot afford the overhead of a standalone database management we need to find a simple DB that can become part of the application The Berkeley DB is this type of but there might be licensing issues I believe there are other but I do not have experience with them I am hoping that a developer with experience in this type of application can be brought on and will give us the pros and cons of a few solutions Failover and load balancing are built into the operating system The thing is that load balancing expects many relatively short lived connections The P3 solution is a single long lived so that would have to be modified to handle the difference Since these are to be the code doesn t have to be general which makes it somewhat simpler The only considerations that have to be made will be for potential upgrades to the appliance hardware The S2 solution is a somewhat different beast Performance will be of some because the file system will wait for a key and then for encryption decryption before it can forward a file to its next destination since it all takes place in a single data center over a high speed we will have more control over performance factors It should be possible to leverage key management from the P3 with some differences in the table definitions And we will use the Mocana encryption without any changes to their code for the encryption engine Also the standard built in failover functionality should work for this solution The biggest challenge here is the agents This requires a strong knowledge of the specific file systems to be supported Finding the right people for this will be critical for delivering a product in a reasonable amount of time With all of that before we begin I would like to have a source code management system in place If Velocite Systems does not already have I recommend subversion The question is where it will reside If there is administrator access to the Velocite Systems web that would be the perfect and the amount of traffic added would be minimal Otherwise a suitable host needs to be designated we need to plan for testing This could be done on a moderately powered server virtual running or a few smaller servers The key is that they need to be set up with procedures and automated scripts established so that whoever needs to run a test can do so efficiently I am assuming that there are plenty of people at Velocite Systems who could handle but we need to plan for how much of their time it will require And last but not least

then establishing a procedure for developers to feed information to this person as functions are completed As far as building the development Bob wants to focus on the P3 solution first The S2 solution could be ramped up while the P3 solution is still being but I am not planning on that happening At this I know what needs to be but I haven t tried to break it out to determine how long it will take Basically I see at least developers for the P3 and maybe including an admin interface Platform because my back is killing me if it is absolutely necessary to meet face to face on Fri

The main focus of the P3 solution is so it has to be lean and mean We have to avoid anything that adds overhead Since there won t be any client applications that connect to the primary and secondary P3 file and web server software is not needed The P3 systems will act like routers and sit in the path of traffic between data centers In fact they will have some low level routing functionality Almost all of this will have to be original but it should not be extremely complicated The Mocana code we will use is the IPSec handler and the encryption engine We will modify the IPSec code slightly The big question is key which is a database application We cannot afford the overhead of a standalone database management we need to find a simple DB that can become part of the application The Berkeley DB is this type of but there might be licensing issues I believe there are other but I do not have experience with them I am hoping that a developer with experience in this type of application can be brought on and will give us the pros and cons of a few solutions Failover and load balancing are built into the operating system The thing is that load balancing expects many relatively short lived connections The P3 solution is a single long lived so that would have to be modified to handle the difference Since these are to be the code doesn t have to be general which makes it somewhat simpler The only considerations that have to be made will be for potential upgrades to the appliance hardware The S2 solution is a somewhat different beast Performance will be of some because the file system will wait for a key and then for encryption decryption before it can forward a file to its next destination since it all takes place in a single data center over a high speed we will have more control over performance factors It should be possible to leverage key management from the P3 with some differences in the table definitions And we will use the Mocana encryption without any changes to their code for the encryption engine Also the standard built in failover functionality should work for this solution The biggest challenge here is the agents This requires a strong knowledge of the specific file systems to be supported Finding the right people for this will be critical for delivering a product in a reasonable amount of time With all of that before we begin I would like to have a source code management system in place If Velocite Systems does not already have I recommend subversion The question is where it will reside If there is administrator access to the Velocite Systems web that would be the perfect and the amount of traffic added would be minimal Otherwise a suitable host needs to be designated we need to plan for testing This could be done on a moderately powered server virtual running or a few smaller servers The key is that they need to be set up with procedures and automated scripts established so that whoever needs to run a test can do so efficiently I am assuming that there are plenty of people at Velocite Systems who could handle but we need to plan for how much of their time it will require And last but not documentation This always requires input from the and if it is left to the last is usually a larger task than you would expect It would be best to have someone in charge of creating the format and then establishing a procedure for developers to feed information to this person as functions are completed As far as building the development Bob wants to focus on the P3 solution first The S2 solution could be ramped up while the P3 solution is still being but I am not planning on that happening At this I know what needs to be but I haven t tried to break it out to determine how long it will take Basically I see at least developers for the P3 and maybe including an admin interface Platform because my back is killing me if it is absolutely necessary to meet face to face on give me a couple of hours notice and I will take an extra Advil and come to Glen Burnie But if you have specific issues you would like to address

The big question is key which is a database application We cannot afford the overhead of a standalone database management we need to find a simple DB that can become part of the application The Berkeley DB is this type of but there might be licensing issues I believe there are other but I do not have experience with them I am hoping that a developer with experience in this type of application can be brought on and will give us the pros and cons of a few solutions Failover and load balancing are built into the operating system The thing is that load balancing expects many relatively short lived connections The P3 solution is a single long lived so that would have to be modified to handle the difference Since these are to be the code doesn t have to be general which makes it somewhat simpler The only considerations that have to be made will be for potential upgrades to the appliance hardware The S2 solution is a somewhat different beast Performance will be of some because the file system will wait for a key and then for encryption decryption before it can forward a file to its next destination since it all takes place in a single data center over a high speed we will have more control over performance factors It should be possible to leverage key management from the P3 with some differences in the table definitions And we will use the Mocana encryption without any changes to their code for the encryption engine Also the standard built in failover functionality should work for this solution The biggest challenge here is the agents This requires a strong knowledge of the specific file systems to be supported Finding the right people for this will be critical for delivering a product in a reasonable amount of time With all of that The main focus of the P3 solution is so it has to be lean and mean We have to avoid anything that adds overhead Since there won t be any client applications that connect to the primary and secondary P3 file and web server software is not needed The P3 systems will act like routers and sit in the path of traffic between data centers In fact they will have some low level routing functionality Almost all of this will have to be original but it should not be extremely complicated The Mocana code we will use is the IPSec handler and the encryption engine We will modify the IPSec code slightly The big question is key which is a database application We cannot afford the overhead of a standalone database management we need to find a simple DB that can become part of the application The Berkeley DB is this type of but there might be licensing issues I believe there are other but I do not have experience with them I am hoping that a developer with experience in this type of application can be brought on and will give us the pros and cons of a few solutions Failover and load balancing are built into the operating system The thing is that load balancing expects many relatively short lived connections The P3 solution is a single long lived so that would have to be modified to handle the difference Since these are to be the code doesn t have to be general which makes it somewhat simpler The only considerations that have to be made will be for potential upgrades to the appliance hardware The S2 solution is a somewhat different beast Performance will be of some because the file system will wait for a key and then for encryption decryption before it can forward a file to its next destination since it all takes place in a single data center over a high speed we will have more control over performance factors It should be possible to leverage key management from the P3 with some differences in the table definitions And we will use the Mocana encryption without any changes to their code for the encryption engine Also the standard built in failover functionality should work for this solution The biggest challenge here is the agents This requires a strong knowledge of the specific file systems to be supported Finding the right people for this will be critical for delivering a product in a reasonable amount of time With all of that before we begin I would like to have a source code management system in place If Velocite Systems does not already have I recommend subversion The question is where it will reside If there is administrator access to the Velocite Systems web that would be the perfect and the amount of traffic added would be minimal Otherwise a suitable host needs to be designated we need to plan for testing This could be done on a moderately powered server virtual running or a few smaller servers The key is that they need to be set up with procedures and automated scripts established so that whoever needs to run a test can do so efficiently I am assuming that there are plenty of people at Velocite Systems who could handle but we need to plan for how much of their time it will require And last but
